Look at me. You will see that I am well fed and clothed, when I am sick a doctor is provided for me, and when I go to church I drive my master's carriage, which I always speak of as 'our' carriage.'. I have been to Cincinnati before, and I have observed your free negroes. They are a mangy, ashy-looking set, often out of employment, with neither the priviledge nor opportunities of the White man. If you could make a white man of me with his rights and priviledge, I would gladly accept the opportunity, and take any and all risks to gain my freedom; but as it is, I prefer to remain my master's slave.
